[**Sampling Theorem**]{}

The greyvalues of digitized one- or two-dimensional signals are
typically generated by an analogue-to-digital converter (ADC), by
sampling a continuous signal at fixed intervals (e.g. in time), and
quantizing (digitizing) the samples. The sampling (or point sampling)
theorem states that a band-limited analogue signal $x_a(t)$, i.e. a
signal in a finite frequency band (e.g. between 0 and BHz), can be
completely reconstructed from its samples $x(n) = x(nT)$, if the
sampling frequency is greater than $2B$ (the Nyquist rate); expressed in
the , this that the sampling interval $T$ is at most $\frac{1}{2B}$
seconds. Undersampling can produce serious errors (aliasing) by
introducing artifacts of low frequencies, both in one-dimensional
signals and in digital .
